Front: Define: dissociate (dih-soh-see-ate)
Back: v. to consider as separate v. to break away When news of the company's fraud broke out, former affiliates tried to dissociate themselves from the partnership. Prefix: dis- (from Latin, meaning “apart” or “away”), Root: soci (from Latin socius, meaning “companion” or “ally”)

Front: Define: dissonant (diss-ih-nunt)
Back: adj. not in agreement; discordant adj. unpleasant or harsh sounding The first song the group performed surprised the audience with its dissonant chords and unusual length. Prefix: dis- (from Latin, meaning “apart” or “away”), Root: son (from Latin sonare, meaning “to sound”), Suffix: -ant (used to form adjectives)

Front: Define: distend (dih-stend)
Back: v. to swell or widen The children watched in fascination as the frog distended its throat and croaked. Prefix: dis- (from Latin, meaning “apart” or “away”), Root: tend (from Latin tendere, meaning “to stretch”)

Front: Define: distill (dih-still)
Back: v. to make pure v. to take out from The essence of the substance was distilled through a complicated process. Prefix: dis- (from Latin, meaning “apart” or “away”), Root: still (from Latin stillare, meaning “to drip”)

Front: Define: divest (dahy-vest)
Back: v. to deprive or dispossess v. to dispose of assets He was divested of his privileges and title after breaking the club's most important rule. Prefix: di- (variant of dis-, meaning “apart” or “away”), Root: vest (from Latin vestire, meaning “to clothe”)

Front: Define: doctrinaire (dock-truh-nair)
Back: adj. following theory without regard for practical reality The new president's doctrinaire attitude towards economics led him to go through with some harmful policies. Root: doctrin (from Latin doctrina, meaning “teaching” or “doctrine”), Suffix: -aire (used to form nouns or adjectives, often indicating a person associated with something)

Front: Define: elate (ee-late)
Back: v. to fill with optimism or excitement Activists were elated to hear about the passage of the civil rights legislation. Prefix: e- (from Latin, meaning “out” or “from”), Root: lat (from Latin latus, meaning “carried” or “borne”)

Front: Define: elegy (ell-ih-djee)
Back: n. a mournful poem or song At her father's funeral, Linda chose to read an elegy by his favorite poet, Keats. Root: eleg (from Greek elegos, meaning “song of mourning”)

Front: Define: elucidate (ih-loo-sih-dehyt)
Back: v. to make easier to understand The company introduced simplified diagrams on its packaging to elucidate its new environmentally-friendly manufacturing process. Prefix: e- (from Latin, meaning “out” or “from”), Root: lucid (from Latin lucidus, meaning “clear”), Suffix: -ate (used to form verbs)

Front: Define: emaciate (ih-mehy-shee-ehyt)
Back: v. to make or become thin He emerged from the prisoner camp emaciated by months of inadequate rations. Prefix: e- (from Latin, meaning “out” or “from”), Root: maciat (from Latin macies, meaning “leanness”), Suffix: -ate (used to form verbs)

Front: Define: emollient (ih-mole-yunt)
Back: adj. having the effect of softening The cream was popular for its moisturizing and emollient properties. Prefix: e- (from Latin, meaning “out” or “from”), Root: moll (from Latin mollis, meaning “soft”), Suffix: -ient (used to form adjectives)

Front: Define: venal (veen-l)
Back: adj. capable of being bought or bribed; mercenary; corruptible Naturally, the case was declared a mistrial when its venal judge was shown to have sought bribes from both the prosecution and the defense. Root: ven (from Latin venalis, meaning “for sale”)

Front: Define: doggerel (daw-ger-uhl)
Back: n. trivial, poorly constructed verse adj. comic, burlesque; loose and irregular The doggerel found in some publications is often a result of lazy editing. Root: dogger (possibly from Middle English doggerel, meaning “worthless”)

Front: Define: manse (manss)
Back: n. a clergyman's house n. a mansion The architect just finished the plans for the minister's new manse. Root: manse (from Latin mansus, meaning “dwelling”)

Front: Define: nexus (nek-suhss)
Back: n. a connected series; a tie or link n. the center or focus The detective pursued several corrupt police officials and so uncovered the nexus of the city's violent crime. Root: nex (from Latin nectere, meaning “to bind” or “to tie”)

Front: Define: promulgate (prom-uhl-geyt)
Back: v. to make openly known; to officially announce The governor promulgated the new building code by special courier to each of the state's municipalities. Prefix: pro- (from Latin, meaning “forward” or “forth”), Root: mulg (from Latin mulgere, meaning “to milk”), Suffix: -ate (used to form verbs)

Front: Define: dross (drawss)
Back: n. rubbish, waste, or foreign matter; impurity Fred dismissed the criticisms of his portfolio, pointing out that the gold had far outweighed the dross through his long career. Root: dross (from Old English dros, meaning “dregs”)

Front: Define: demur (duh-mur)
Back: v. to take exception; to object n. an objection Though he was essentially in favor of freedom of speech, he demurred at certain types of hate speech. Prefix: de- (from Latin, meaning “down” or “away”), Root: mur (from Latin mora, meaning “delay”)

Front: Define: felicitous (fih-liss-ih-tuss)
Back: adj. appropriate, suitable (as of a comment); well-chosen Though Zhang and Eric are nothing alike, their complementary strengths made for a felicitous pairing as lab partners. Root: felic (from Latin felicitas, meaning “happiness”), Suffix: -ous (used to form adjectives)

Front: Define: veritable (ver-ih-tuh-buhl)
Back: adj. authentic, real, true In such a moderate district, winning more than 60 percent of the vote is a veritable landslide. Root: verit (from Latin veritas, meaning “truth”), Suffix: -able (used to form adjectives)

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to consider as separate v. to break away Hint: starts with “d”
Back: dissociate synonyms: separate, detach, disjoin, disconnect, disengage It's important to dissociate your personal feelings from your professional decisions. After the argument, she chose to dissociate herself from the group.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ______ chords in the song created an unsettling atmosphere. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “lacking harmony or agreement”.
Back: dissonant dissonant (diss-ih-nunt) adj. not in agreement; discordant adj. unpleasant or harsh sounding

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to swell or widen Hint: starts with “d”
Back: distend synonyms: bulge, swell, bloat, expand, inflate The balloon began to distend as more air was pumped into it. After the big meal, my stomach started to distend, making me uncomfortable.

Front: Fill in the blank: The process to ______ the alcohol took several hours to ensure purity. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “to purify or extract the essence of”.
Back: distill distill (dih-still) v. to make pure v. to take out from

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to deprive or dispossess v. to dispose of assets Hint: starts with “d”
Back: divest synonyms: release, give up possession, rid, disencumber, unload The company decided to divest its non-core business units to focus on its main operations. She felt it was time to divest herself of unnecessary possessions.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ______ approach to politics often led to conflicts with more pragmatic colleagues. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “stubbornly attached to a theory”.
Back: doctrinaire doctrinaire (dock-truh-nair) adj. following theory without regard for practical reality

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to fill with optimism or excitement Hint: starts with “e”
Back: elate synonyms: uplift, exalt, to make very proud or happy, inspire, thrill, elevate The news of her promotion will surely elate her family.

Front: Fill in the blank: The poet wrote an ______ to honor the fallen soldiers. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “a poem or song of mourning”.
Back: elegy elegy (ell-ih-djee) n. a mournful poem or song

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to make easier to understand Hint: starts with “e”
Back: elucidate synonyms: clarify, simplify, expose, explain, illuminate The professor used diagrams to elucidate complex theories.

Front: Fill in the blank: The prolonged illness caused him to become ______ rapidly. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “to make abnormally thin or weak”.
Back: emaciated emaciate (ih-mehy-shee-ehyt) v. to make or become thin

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. having the effect of softening Hint: starts with “e”
Back: emollient synonyms: relaxing, relieving, soothing, calming, pacifying The emollient cream helped soothe her dry skin.

Front: Fill in the blank: The politician's ______ actions raised concerns about his integrity. Hint: Starts with “v” and means “open to bribery or corruption”.
Back: venal venal (veen-l) adj. capable of being bought or bribed; mercenary

Front: Name the vocab term: n. trivial, poorly constructed verse Hint: starts with “d”
Back: doggerel synonyms: awkward, droll, simplistic, crude, trivial His poem was more doggerel than art, lacking depth and meaning.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ______ hosted the church's community events. Hint: Starts with “m” and means “a clergy member's residence”.
Back: manse manse (manss) n. a clergyman's house n. a mansion

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a connected series; a tie or link n. the center or focus Hint: starts with “n”
Back: nexus synonyms: web, union; core, connection, focal point The nexus between the two research teams led to groundbreaking discoveries. The conference served as the nexus for industry leaders to discuss innovative strategies.

Front: Fill in the blank: The organization will ______ the new policy at the upcoming meeting. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “to make widely known or put into effect”.
Back: promulgate promulgate (prom-uhl-geyt) v. to make openly known; to officially announce

Front: Name the vocab term: n. slag, waste, or foreign matter; impurity Hint: starts with “d”
Back: dross synonyms: dregs, scum, waste, refuse, residue The factory removed the dross from the metal to ensure its purity.

Front: Fill in the blank: She decided to ______ when asked to sign the controversial petition. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “to raise objections or hesitate”.
Back: demur demur (duh-mur) v. to take exception; to object n. an objection

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. appropriate, suitable (as of a comment); well-chosen Hint: starts with “f”
Back: felicitous synonyms: apt, fitting, favorable, timely, relevant His felicitous remarks during the ceremony made everyone feel welcomed.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ______ evidence presented in court changed the case's outcome. Hint: Starts with “v” and means “real or genuine”.
Back: veritable veritable (ver-ih-tuh-buhl) adj. authentic, real, true

Front: Define: impassive (im-pass-iv)
Back: adj. showing no emotion; stoic; unmoved Who could remain impassive after such a heart-wrenching story? Prefix: im- (from Latin, meaning “not”), Root: pass (from Latin passivus, meaning “suffering” or “feeling”)

Front: Define: hermetic (hur-met-ik)
Back: adj. airtight, impervious to outside influence; isolated The tomb's hermetic seal had never been opened. Root: Hermes (from Greek mythology, referring to Hermes Trismegistus, associated with alchemy and sealed containers)

Front: Define: fracas (frey-kuhs)
Back: n. a noisy fight or quarrel In the middle of the day, a fracas between two cab drivers erupted in the street. Root: frac (from Italian fracassare, meaning “to smash” or “to crash”)

Front: Define: eminence (em-ih-nunce)
Back: n. a place of high rank Late in her career, Aida was finally recognized for achieving eminence in filmmaking. Root: emin (from Latin eminere, meaning “to stand out”), Suffix: -ence (from Latin, indicating a state or condition)

Front: Define: epigram (ep-ih-gram)
Back: n. a witty saying The comedian became famous for his instantly recognizable epigrams and one-liners. Prefix: epi- (from Greek, meaning “upon” or “at”), Root: gram (from Greek gramma, meaning “something written”)

Front: Define: epitome (uh-pit-uh-mee)
Back: n. a particularly worthy example of a class or type The salon's customers praised his work as the epitome of high-class hairstyling. Prefix: epi- (from Greek, meaning “upon”), Root: tom (from Greek temnein, meaning “to cut”)

Front: Define: equanimity (ek-wuh-nim-ih-tee)
Back: n. steadiness of mind A good leader maintains her equanimity even during a crisis. Prefix: equi- (from Latin aequus, meaning “equal”), Root: anim (from Latin animus, meaning “mind” or “spirit”), Suffix: -ity (from Latin, indicating a state or condition)

Front: Define: equivocal (uh-kwiv-uh-kul)
Back: adj. uncertain or open to interpretation The doctor's conclusion was rather equivocal, so I asked for a second opinion. Prefix: equi- (from Latin aequus, meaning “equal”), Root: voc (from Latin vocare, meaning “to call”), Suffix: -al (from Latin, forming adjectives)

Front: Define: erudite (air-ya-dahyt)
Back: adj. having profound knowledge or wisdom The erudite professor was extremely knowledgeable but difficult to understand in lectures. Prefix: e- (from Latin, meaning “out of”), Root: rud (from Latin rudis, meaning “untrained” or “rough”), Suffix: -ite (from Latin, forming adjectives)

Front: Define: espouse (uh-spouz)
Back: v. to give or take in matrimony v. to take up or adopt (e.g., a cause) Although she claims to be nonconformist, Becky merely espouses the same beliefs she has read about in various books and websites. Prefix: e- (from Latin, meaning “out of”), Root: spouse (from Latin sponsus, meaning “betrothed”)

Front: Define: eradicate (ih-rad-ih-kehyt)
Back: v. to eliminate completely The poison succeeded in eradicating all of the insects that had invaded the house. Prefix: e- (from Latin, meaning “out of”), Root: radic (from Latin radix, meaning “root”), Suffix: -ate (from Latin, forming verbs)

Front: Define: estrange (ih-strange)
Back: v. to arouse hostility in v. to remove from a group or relationship A particularly mean-spirited remark from her stepmother finally estranged Maggie from her family, and she has not been home since. Prefix: e- (from Latin, meaning “out of”), Root: strange (from Latin extraneus, meaning “foreign”)

Front: Define: evanescent (ev-ih-ness-unt)
Back: adj. tending to vanish The evanescent beauty of cherry blossoms may have inspired the respect for short-lived pleasures evident in the Japanese psyche. Prefix: e- (from Latin, meaning “out of”), Root: vanesc (from Latin vanescere, meaning “to vanish”), Suffix: -ent (from Latin, forming adjectives)

Front: Define: extrinsic (ik-strin-zik)
Back: adj. originating from the outside The parents' cheers were useful for extrinsic motivation, but the coach told the team that the drive to win must come from inside themselves. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning “out of”), Root: trinsic (from Latin intrinsecus, meaning “inward”)

Front: Define: exult (ig-zult)
Back: v. to express joy or elation The winning candidate's campaign team began to exult the moment they heard the news. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning “out of”), Root: ult (from Latin saltare, meaning “to leap”)

Front: Define: facetious (fuh-see-shuss)
Back: adj. humorous with a sarcastic tone The student's facetious comments were seen as disrespectful by his professor. Root: facet (from Latin facetus, meaning “witty”), Suffix: -ious (from Latin, forming adjectives)

Front: Define: facile (fass-ul)
Back: adj. done with ease adj. shallow, uncomplicated Though facile references to cooperation may inspire some workers, others remain unconvinced until their higher-ups go into specifics. Root: fac (from Latin facilis, meaning “easy”)

Front: Define: rectitude (rek-tih-tood)
Back: n. moral righteousness n. the quality of being right The priest praised him for his rectitude in the face of temptation. Root: rect (from Latin rectus, meaning “straight”), Suffix: -itude (from Latin, indicating a state or condition)

Front: Define: crucible (kroo-suh-buhl)
Back: n. a metal container made of heat resistant material n. a severe test n. a place or time characterized by powerful forces He was cast into the crucible of depression by his daughter's diagnosis. Root: cruc (from Latin crux, meaning “cross”), Suffix: -ible (from Latin, forming nouns)

Front: Define: ingenue (an-je-noo)
Back: n. a naive, innocent young woman Do you take me for an ingenue who has never been to the city? Root: gen (from Latin ingenuus, meaning “freeborn” or “noble”)

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. showing no emotion; stoic; unmoved Hint: starts with “i”
Back: impassive synonyms: apathetic, unfeeling, expressionless, emotionless, cold Despite the chaos around him, he remained impassive.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ______ seal ensured that no air entered the container. Hint: Starts with “h” and means “airtight or closed off”.
Back: hermetic hermetic (hur-met-ik) adj. airtight, impervious to outside influence; isolated

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a noisy fight or quarrel Hint: starts with “f”
Back: fracas synonyms: disturbance, fight, brawl, uproar, altercation The fracas in the street drew the attention of nearby residents.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ______ in the field of science earned him numerous awards. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “high rank or importance”.
Back: eminence eminence (em-ih-nunce) n. a place of high rank

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a witty saying Hint: starts with “e”
Back: epigram synonyms: quirk, joke, adage, wisecrack His witty epigram perfectly captured the absurdity of the situation.

Front: Fill in the blank: She is the ______ of professionalism in her field. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “a perfect example”.
Back: epitome epitome (uh-pit-uh-mee) n. a particularly worthy example of a class or type

Front: Name the vocab term: n. steadiness of mind Hint: starts with “e”
Back: equanimity synonyms: composure, poise, calmness, serenity He handled the crisis with remarkable equanimity.

Front: Fill in the blank: The CEO's ______ response left many questions unanswered. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “open to more than one interpretation”.
Back: equivocal equivocal (uh-kwiv-uh-kul) adj. uncertain or open to interpretation

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. having profound knowledge or wisdom Hint: starts with “e”
Back: erudite synonyms: educated, cultured, savvy, knowledgeable The erudite professor was a favorite among students for his deep insights.

Front: Fill in the blank: They decided to ______ their commitment to environmental sustainability by starting a community garden. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “to adopt or support a cause”.
Back: espouse espouse (uh-spouz) v. to give or take in matrimony v. to take up or adopt (e.g., a cause)

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to eliminate completely Hint: starts with “e”
Back: eradicate synonyms: destroy, annihilate, eliminate, exterminate The organization aims to eradicate poverty in the community.

Front: Fill in the blank: His harsh comments served to ______ him from his closest friends. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “to cause to be unfriendly or alienated”.
Back: estrange estrange (ih-strange) v. to arouse hostility in v. to remove oneself from a group or relationship

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. tending to vanish Hint: starts with “e”
Back: evanescent synonyms: transient, disappearing, vanishing, fleeting, momentary The evanescent beauty of the sunset left everyone in awe.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ______ factors influencing the market include global events and trends. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “not inherent or essential”.
Back: extrinsic extrinsic (ik-strin-zik) adj. originating from the outside

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to express joy or elation Hint: starts with “e”
Back: exult synonyms: delight, jubilate, rejoice, celebrate The team began to exult after their hard-fought victory in the championship game.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ______ remarks during the meeting lightened the mood but also annoyed some colleagues. Hint: Starts with “f” and means “joking inappropriately about serious matters”.
Back: facetious facetious (fuh-see-shuss) adj. humorous with a sarcastic tone

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. done with ease Hint: starts with “f”
Back: facile synonyms: effortless, simplistic, easy, superficial The athlete's facile performance made it look effortless.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ______ was evident in his unwavering commitment to justice. Hint: Starts with “r” and means “moral uprightness”.
Back: rectitude rectitude (rek-tih-tood) n. moral righteousness; n. the quality of being right

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a metal container made of heat resistant material Hint: starts with “c”
Back: crucible synonyms: vessel; calamity, trial, test, challenge, ordeal The blacksmith used a crucible to melt the metal for his new creation.

Front: Fill in the blank: The film featured an ______ who captured everyone's hearts with her innocence. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “an innocent or naive young woman”.
Back: ingenue ingenue (an-je-noo) n. a naive, innocent young woman

Front: Define: cadge (kadj)
Back: v. to beg or ask for; to impose on another's generosity The drunk was cadging cigarettes from strangers. Root: cadge (origin uncertain, possibly from Middle English cadge, meaning “to carry”)

Front: Define: flout (flahwt)
Back: v. to demonstrate contempt for; to mock with disdain v. to disregard, to disobey She flouted convention with her bizarre style of dress. Root: flout (from Middle English flouten, meaning “to play the flute” or “to mock”)

Front: Define: ennui (ahn-wee)
Back: n. dissatisfaction and restlessness due to boredom or apathy Go Fish could not cure our rainy-day ennui. Root: ennui (from Old French enui, meaning “annoyance” or “boredom”)

Front: Define: urbanity (ur-ban-ih-tee)
Back: n. refinement and elegance of manner; polished courtesy It was difficult not to be captivated by the palpable urbanity in everything she said. Root: urban (from Latin urbanus, meaning “of the city”)

Front: Define: vicissitude (vih-siss-ih-tood)
Back: n. a sudden, unexpected change, as in one's life John found inner strength and confronted the vicissitudes of a troubled life admirably. Root: viciss (from Latin vicis, meaning “change” or “alternation”)

Front: Define: hubris (hyoo-bris)
Back: n. arrogant presumption, excessive pride The president's hubris led to the desertion of many of his erstwhile friends who missed the humble and prudent politician they once knew. Root: hubris (from Greek hybris, meaning “excessive pride”)

Front: Define: fallow (fal-owe)
Back: adj. undeveloped (often despite the potential to be used) In the United States, some farmers are paid to leave parts of their land fallow in order to limit agricultural output. Root: fallow (from Old English fealgian, meaning “to break up land for sowing”)

Front: Define: fathom (fath-um)
Back: v. to calculate the depth of v. to comprehend I cannot even fathom the idea of giving up my child for adoption. Root: fathom (from Old English fæthm, meaning “to embrace” or “to encircle”)

Front: Define: fatuous (fach-oo-us)
Back: adj. inanely foolish Most of his peers and relations thought his dream of becoming both a doctor and astronaut was fatuous at best. Root: fatu (from Latin fatuus, meaning “foolish”)

Front: Define: ferment (v. fur-ment; n. fur-ment)
Back: v. to process sugar into alcohol organically v. to work up n. a state of excitement or turbulence The ferment into which Watson and Crick's discovery of DNA thrust the world of evolutionary biology was slow to die down. Root: ferment (from Latin fermentum, meaning “leaven” or “yeast”)

Front: Define: fervent (fur-vent)
Back: adj. filled with strong emotion Her fervent desire to help others led her to start her own charity organization with her inheritance. Root: ferv (from Latin fervere, meaning “to boil” or “to be hot”)

Front: Define: fetter (fet-er)
Back: n. a restraint v. to restrict or restrain The designer felt his creativity was fettered by his client's demands. Root: fetter (from Old English feter, meaning “chain” or “shackle”)

Front: Define: garrulous (gair-uh-luss)
Back: adj. overly talkative (esp. about unimportant topics) The woman's garrulous nature annoyed most of her coworkers. Root: garrul (from Latin garrulus, meaning “talkative”)

Front: Define: gauche (goash)
Back: adj. unsophisticated; lacking manners Linda kept to herself at her boss's cocktail party, lest she say something gauche and embarrass herself. Root: gauche (from French gauche, meaning “left” or “awkward”)

Front: Define: germane (djer-mehyn)
Back: adj. relevant to the matter at hand Kevin had a hard time finding materials that were actually germane to his project and not just tangentially related. Root: germ (from Latin germanus, meaning “related” or “pertinent”)

Front: Define: glib (glihb)
Back: adj. spoken in a smooth, unconcerned manner adj. informal to the point of being insincere The politician annoyed many journalists with his glib responses. Root: glib (from Middle Low German glibberig, meaning “slippery”)

Front: Define: glutton (glut-un)
Back: n. a person who eats to excess Johnny got in trouble so often that his professors began asking if he was a “glutton for punishment”. Root: glutt (from Latin gluttire, meaning “to swallow”)

Front: Define: grandiloquent (gran-dill-ih-kwunt)
Back: adj. extravagant and pompous in speech The grandiloquent speech did not have much substance, leaving the audience confused about its purpose. Prefix: grand (from Latin grandis, meaning “large”) Suffix: loquent (from Latin loqui, meaning “to speak”)

Front: Define: gratuitous (gruh-too-ih-tuss)
Back: adj. unwarranted or unnecessary The movie disgusted her due to its gratuitous violence, which served no plot function so far as she could tell. Root: gratuit (from Latin gratuitus, meaning “free” or “unearned”)

Front: Define: gregarious (grih-gair-ee-us)
Back: adj. outgoing and friendly adj. tending to live in communities This gregarious species of bird may be found in flocks of up to one hundred individuals. Root: greg (from Latin grex, meaning “flock” or “herd”)

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to beg or ask for; to impose on another's generosity Hint: starts with “c”
Back: cadge synonyms: hawk, mooch, scrounge, solicit The artist would often cadge a meal from friends during tough times.

Front: Fill in the blank: He chose to ______ the dress code by wearing jeans to the formal event. Hint: Starts with “f” and means “to openly disregard rules or norms”.
Back: flout flout (flahwt) v. to demonstrate contempt for; to mock with disdain

Front: Name the vocab term: n. dissatisfaction and restlessness due to boredom or apathy Hint: starts with “e”
Back: ennui synonyms: tedium, weariness, disinterest, boredom, listlessness The rainy day brought a sense of ennui that made everyone feel lethargic.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ______ was evident in the way she addressed every guest at the party. Hint: Starts with “u” and means “refined and courteous manner”.
Back: urbanity urbanity (ur-ban-ih-tee) n. refinement and elegance of manner; polished courtesy

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a sudden, unexpected change, as in one's life Hint: starts with “v”
Back: vicissitude synonyms: alteration, hardship, adversity, fluctuation, change The vicissitude of the economy left many families struggling to make ends meet.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ______ ultimately led to his downfall, as he ignored the advice of seasoned experts. Hint: Starts with “h” and means “excessive pride or self-confidence”.
Back: hubris hubris (hyoo-bris) n. arrogant presumption, excessive pride

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. undeveloped (often despite the potential to be used) Hint: starts with “f”
Back: fallow synonyms: neglected, inactive, vacant, unused, barren The fallow land was finally cultivated after years of neglect.

Front: Fill in the blank: The diver used a special device to ______ the depth of the ocean at that location. Hint: Starts with “f” and means “to understand deeply”.
Back: fathom fathom (fath-um) v. to calculate the depth of v. to comprehend

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. inanely foolish Hint: starts with “f”
Back: fatuous synonyms: silly, frivolous, absurd, witless His fatuous assumption that he could ace the final without studying cost him his scholarship.

Front: Fill in the blank: As the project progressed, the team began to ______ new ideas and strategies. Hint: Starts with “f” and means “to incite or stir up trouble”.
Back: ferment ferment (v. fur-ment; n. fur-ment) v. to process sugar into alcohol organically v. to work up n. a state of excitement or turbulence

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. filled with strong emotion Hint: starts with “f”
Back: fervent synonyms: ardent, zealous, impassioned; passionate, intense Her fervent desire to help others led her to start her own charity organization.

Front: Fill in the blank: The judge imposed a ______ to ensure the defendant did not leave the country. Hint: Starts with “f” and means “a restraint, or to restrict or chain”.
Back: fetter fetter (fet-er) n. a restraint v. to restrict or restrain

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. overly talkative (esp. about unimportant topics) Hint: starts with “g”
Back: garrulous synonyms: babbling, chatty, verbose; loquacious, talkative The woman's garrulous nature annoyed most of her coworkers.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ______ remarks at the dinner party made everyone feel uncomfortable. Hint: Starts with “g” and means “lacking social grace”.
Back: gauche gauche (goash) adj. unsophisticated; lacking manners

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. relevant to the matter at hand Hint: starts with “g”
Back: germane synonyms: appropriate, applicable, befitting, pertinent, related The professor emphasized that only germane questions would be addressed during the discussion.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ______ remarks during the meeting failed to address the real issues at hand. Hint: Starts with “g” and means “fluent but insincere”.
Back: glib glib (glihb) adj. spoken in a smooth, unconcerned manner adj. informal to the point of being insincere

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a person who eats to excess Hint: starts with “g”
Back: glutton synonyms: gorger, hog, overeater, devourer The glutton at the buffet piled his plate high, showing no signs of stopping.

Front: Fill in the blank: The politician's ______ speech was filled with flowery language but lacked substance. Hint: Starts with “g” and means “using lofty or pompous language”.
Back: grandiloquent grandiloquent (gran-dill-ih-kwunt) adj. extravagant and pompous in speech

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. unwarranted or unnecessary Hint: starts with “g”
Back: gratuitous synonyms: unneeded, wanton, excessive, redundant The film's gratuitous violence overshadowed its otherwise compelling storyline.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ______ nature made it easy for her to make friends wherever she went. Hint: Starts with “g” and means “sociable and outgoing”.
Back: gregarious gregarious (grih-gair-ee-us) adj. outgoing and friendly adj. tending to live in communities

Front: Define: guile (gahyl)
Back: n. trickery or duplicity His offer was free of guile and meant only to be helpful. Root: guile (from Old French guile, meaning “deceit” or “trickery”)

Front: Define: hyperbole (hahy-pur-buh-lee)
Back: n. exaggeration The statement that “I'm so hungry, I could eat a cow,” is hyperbole and not meant to be taken literally. Prefix: hyper- (from Greek hyper, meaning “over” or “beyond”); Root: bole (from Greek ballein, meaning “to throw”)

Front: Define: iconoclast (eye-con-uh-klast)
Back: n. one who challenges generally accepted beliefs and traditions The iconoclasts who upended Britain's post-war consensus took a much harder line against unions than had been the norm. Root: icon (from Greek eikon, meaning “image” or “likeness”); Suffix: -clast (from Greek klastes, meaning “breaker”)

Front: Define: idiosyncrasy (id-ee-owe-sing-kruh-see)
Back: n. a peculiar way of behaving or thinking His obsession with removing his shoes the moment they got wet was one of his many idiosyncrasies. Prefix: idio- (from Greek idios, meaning “own” or “peculiar”); Root: syn (from Greek syn, meaning “together”); Suffix: -crasy (from Greek krasis, meaning “mixture”)

Front: Define: idyll (ahyd-ul)
Back: n. a scene of simple and tranquil nature n. a short poem about such a scene Her favorite poems are idylls about the joys of life in the country. Root: idyll (from Greek eidyllion, meaning “little picture” or “form”)

Front: Define: immutable (ih-mew-tuh-bull)
Back: adj. not susceptible to change The actors knew that once the director made a decision about a scene, it was immutable and not open to debate. Prefix: im- (from Latin in, meaning “not”); Root: mutable (from Latin mutabilis, meaning “changeable”)

Front: Define: imperious (im-peer-ee-us)
Back: adj. proud and arrogant The actress replied to her manager's concerns with an imperious wave of her hand. Prefix: im- (from Latin in, meaning “in” or “on”); Root: per (from Latin parare, meaning “to prepare”); Suffix: -ious (forming adjectives, meaning “having the qualities of”)

Front: Define: impetuous (im-pech-oo-us)
Back: adj. hasty and lacking in thought His impetuous and eager nature led him to take on more projects than he could realistically complete. Prefix: im- (from Latin in, meaning “in” or “on”); Root: pet (from Latin petere, meaning “to seek” or “to go to”); Suffix: -uous (forming adjectives, meaning “having the quality of”)

Front: Define: impetus (im-pih-tuss)
Back: n. a force that encourages or pushes forward a certain activity n. a force that moves an object The sudden publicity around the violence in India gave impetus to the campaign to end the conflict through international mediation. Prefix: im- (from Latin in, meaning “in” or “on”); Root: petus (from Latin petere, meaning “to seek” or “to go to”)

Front: Define: implacable (im-plack-ih-bull)
Back: adj. impossible to calm or satisfy According to my mother, I was an implacable baby who often kept her up through the night. Prefix: im- (from Latin in, meaning “not”); Root: plac (from Latin placare, meaning “to please” or “to appease”); Suffix: -able (forming adjectives, meaning “capable of”)

Front: Define: inert (in-urt)
Back: adj. not able to move adj. having no energy or interest adj. chemically inactive After hours at the gym, Luke could only lie about the house, inert and exhausted. Prefix: in- (from Latin in, meaning “not”); Root: ert (from Latin ars, meaning “skill” or “art”)

Front: Define: infallible (in-fal-ih-bull)
Back: adj. incapable of error Many of the actor's fans considered him infallible, so it was shocking when his latest film was widely panned. Prefix: in- (from Latin in, meaning “not”); Root: fall (from Latin fallere, meaning “to deceive”); Suffix: -ible (forming adjectives, meaning “capable of”)

Front: Define: ingenuous (in-djehn-you-us)
Back: adj. unable to mask feelings adj. lacking worldliness; innocent and unsuspecting Kate was too ingenuous to realize that accepting a ride from a stranger might be a bad idea. Prefix: in- (from Latin in, meaning “in” or “on”); Root: genu (from Latin gignere, meaning “to beget”); Suffix: -ous (forming adjectives, meaning “having the quality of”)

Front: Define: iniquitous (ih-nick-wih-tuss)
Back: adj. wicked or unjust The villain's iniquitous plan was fortunately foiled again by the hero. Prefix: in- (from Latin in, meaning “not”); Root: iquit (from Latin aequus, meaning “equal” or “just”); Suffix: -ous (forming adjectives, meaning “having the quality of”)

Front: Define: innocuous (ih-nock-you-us)
Back: adj. not likely to injure or harm adj. not controversial adj. uninspiring or uninteresting This insect looks dangerous and frightening but is actually innocuous. Prefix: in- (from Latin in, meaning “not”); Root: nocu (from Latin nocere, meaning “to harm”); Suffix: -ous (forming adjectives, meaning “having the quality of”)

Front: Define: inoculate (ih-nock-yuh-late)
Back: v. to vaccinate; to introduce an idea/attitude into the mind of In most states, children must be inoculated against common diseases before they enter public school. Prefix: in- (from Latin in, meaning “in” or “on”); Root: ocul (from Latin oculus, meaning “eye”); Suffix: -ate (forming verbs, meaning “to make”)

Front: Define: insolence (in-suh-lunce)
Back: n. rudeness; a lack of respect When she could no longer stand the child's insolence, the babysitter called his parents to complain. Prefix: in- (from Latin in, meaning “not”); Root: solent (from Latin solere, meaning “to be accustomed”); Suffix: -ence (forming nouns, meaning “state or quality of”)

Front: Define: insular (in-suh-lurr)
Back: adj. limited in outlook adj. physically or emotionally removed from others Having grown up in a small, insular town her whole life, Linda longed to move to a big city. Root: insul (from Latin insula, meaning “island”); Suffix: -ar (forming adjectives, meaning “relating to”)

Front: Define: intractable (in-track-tuh-bull)
Back: adj. not easily managed or governed adj. not easily manipulated or molded adj. not easily treated The horse was too intractable to be used in the race. Prefix: in- (from Latin in, meaning “not”); Root: tract (from Latin tractare, meaning “to handle” or “to manage”); Suffix: -able (forming adjectives, meaning “capable of”)

Front: Define: laconic (luh-con-ik)
Back: adj. brief and direct, often to the point of seeming rude Kevin's laconic response was unfortunately perceived as a rebuff and he was not invited to any more gatherings. Root: lacon (from Greek Lakōn, referring to the region of Laconia, known for its terse speech); Suffix: -ic (forming adjectives, meaning “having the nature of”)

Front: Name the vocab term: n. trickery or duplicity Hint: starts with “g”
Back: guile synonyms: slyness, deceit, cunning, trickery, deception The con artist used guile to swindle unsuspecting victims out of their savings.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her claim that she could run a mile in under four minutes was pure ______. Hint: Starts with “h” and means “exaggeration for effect”.
Back: hyperbole hyperbole (hahy-pur-buh-lee) n. exaggeration

Front: Name the vocab term: n. one who challenges generally accepted beliefs and traditions Hint: starts with “i”
Back: iconoclast synonyms: detractor, cynic, dissenter, rebel, nonconformist As an iconoclast, he often questioned the status quo and pushed for innovative ideas.

Front: Fill in the blank: His habit of wearing mismatched socks was just one of his many ______. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “a unique personal trait”.
Back: idiosyncrasies idiosyncrasy (id-ee-owe-sing-kruh-see) n. a peculiar way of behaving or thinking

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a scene of simple and tranquil nature n. a short poem about such a scene Hint: starts with “i”
Back: idyll synonyms: ballad, lyric, pastoral, tranquil scene, haven The garden was an idyll, with blooming flowers and gentle breezes that brought a sense of peace. The poet composed an idyll celebrating the beauty of a quiet countryside at dawn.

Front: Fill in the blank: The laws of physics are considered ______, remaining constant regardless of circumstances. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “unchanging over time”.
Back: immutable immutable (ih-mew-tuh-bull) adj. not susceptible to change

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. proud and arrogant Hint: starts with “i”
Back: imperious synonyms: haughty, domineering, overbearing, arrogant. Her imperious demeanor made it clear that she expected everyone to obey her commands without question.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ______ decision to quit his job without a backup plan left him in a difficult situation. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “acting hastily without thought”.
Back: impetuous impetuous (im-pech-oo-us) adj. hasty and lacking in thought

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a force that encourages or pushes forward a certain activity n. a force that moves an object Hint: starts with “i”
Back: impetus synonyms: driving force, push, incentive, momentum, stimulus The grant provided the impetus for the researchers to expand their study. The wind acted as an impetus, propelling the sailboat swiftly across the water.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ______ anger left no room for negotiation after the betrayal. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “unable to be appeased”.
Back: implacable implacable (im-plack-ih-bull) adj. impossible to calm or satisfy

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. not able to move adj. having no energy or interest adj. chemically inactive Hint: starts with “i”
Back: inert synonyms: lifeless, still, inactive, dormant, motionless, sluggish, torpid The heavy boulder remained inert on the hillside, refusing to budge. After a long day at work, I felt completely inert and unable to do anything productive.

Front: Fill in the blank: The scientist believed his method was ______, but unforeseen variables led to unexpected results. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “incapable of being wrong”.
Back: infallible infallible (in-fal-ih-bull) adj. incapable of error

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. unable to mask feelings adj. lacking worldliness; innocent or unsuspecting Hint: starts with “i”
Back: ingenuous synonyms: direct, genuine, naive, straightforward, innocent, candid His ingenuous expression revealed his true emotions, making it clear how he felt. The ingenuous child believed every word in the fairy tale, unaware of the harsh realities of life.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ______ practices of the corrupt regime shocked the international community. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “grossly unfair or immoral”.
Back: iniquitous iniquitous (ih-nick-wih-tuss) adj. wicked or unjust

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. not likely to injure or harm adj. not controversial adj. uninspiring or uninteresting Hint: starts with “i”
Back: innocuous synonyms: harmless, drab, safe, benign, insipid The new policy was designed to be innocuous, ensuring that it would not adversely affect any employees. Her comments were innocuous, sparking no debates or disagreements among the group.

Front: Fill in the blank: The doctor will ______ you against the flu this season. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “to protect against disease by introducing a vaccine”.
Back: inoculate inoculate (ih-nock-yuh-late) v. to vaccinate; to introduce an idea/attitude into the mind of

Front: Name the vocab term: n. rudeness; a lack of respect Hint: starts with “i”
Back: insolence synonyms: nerve, impudence, rudeness, disrespect, audacity His insolence towards the teacher resulted in a detention.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ______ perspective made it difficult for him to understand viewpoints different from his own. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “narrow-minded or isolated”.
Back: insular insular (in-suh-lurr) adj. limited in outlook adj. physically or emotionally removed from others

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. not easily managed or governed adj. not easily manipulated or molded adj. not easily treated Hint: starts with “i”
Back: intractable synonyms: unresponsive, refractory, stubborn, difficult, obstinate The intractable patient refused to follow the treatment plan, making it challenging for the doctors to help him. The intractable problem continued to baffle the researchers, who struggled to find a solution.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ______ replies made it hard to tell what he was really thinking. Hint: Starts with “l” and means “using very few words”.
Back: laconic laconic (luh-con-ik) adj. brief and direct, often to the point of seeming rude

Front: Define: lampoon (lam-poon)
Back: n. a sharp satire mocking a person or group through an artistic medium v. to satirize or attack in such a style Many modern comedies focus solely on lampooning typical films from a variety of genres. Root: lamp- (from French lampon, meaning “let us drink”)

Front: Define: latent (lehy-tent)
Back: adj. present or existing but not currently visible The doctor explained that she had died of a latent heart condition that was not detected until it was too late to treat. Root: lat- (from Latin latere, meaning “to lie hidden”)

Front: Define: lattice (lat-is)
Back: n. a pattern consisting of, or resembling, an interwoven frame made by crisscrossing strips The back of the antique mirror was made of a lattice of rich, dark wood. Root: latt- (from Latin latticium, meaning “lattice work”)

Front: Define: laud (lawd)
Back: v. to praise or glorify When he returned home, his relatives and friends lauded him for his bravery on the battlefield. Root: laud- (from Latin laudare, meaning “to praise”)

Front: Define: leaven (lev-un)
Back: v. to have an enlivening or lightening influence The few jokes he threw in did nothing to leaven his grim sermon. Root: lev- (from Latin levare, meaning “to raise”)

Front: Define: lethargic (luh-thar-djick)
Back: adj. physically or mentally slow Although I have gotten over the worst of my illness, I am still too lethargic to do anything but stay in bed. Root: letharg- (from Greek lēthargos, meaning “forgetful”)

Front: Define: levy (lev-ee)
Back: v. to impose and collect n. a charge imposed The government decided that the best way to deal with the problem was to levy a new tax on the ownership of pets. Root: lev- (from Latin levare, meaning “to raise”)

Front: Define: mean (meen)
Back: adj. low in status or quality n. a point between two extremes Ali is a moderate, preferring to choose the mean when faced with extreme leftist and rightist arguments. Root: mean- (from Old English gemǣne, meaning “common”)

Front: Define: meander (mee-an-dur)
Back: v. to wander in a leisurely manner I have a tendency to meander about my large garden when I'm bored. Root: meander- (from Greek Maiandros, a river known for its winding course)

Front: Define: medley (med-lee)
Back: n. a mixture of dissimilar things n. a musical composition of melodies from different songs The local singing group is renowned for their medley of popular Beatles songs. Root: med- (from Old French mesler, meaning “to mix”)

Front: Define: melancholy (mel-un-kol-ee)
Back: n. a feeling of deep sadness adj. sad, dejected After her husband's departure, she spent months wallowing in melancholy. Root: melan- (from Greek melas, meaning “black”) and chol- (from Greek chole, meaning “bile”)

Front: Define: mercurial (mur-cure-ee-ul)
Back: adj. subject to sudden changes in mood adj. lively and quick My mother's mercurial temperament makes it impossible to predict how she will react to bad news. Root: mercur- (from Latin Mercurius, the Roman god Mercury, known for his speed and changeability)

Front: Define: monotonous (muh-not-ih-nuss)
Back: adj. tedious, repetitive adj. characterized by a tone of unvarying pitch My new job consists of putting letters into envelopes, organizing files in alphabetical order, and other monotonous tasks. Prefix: mono- (from Greek monos, meaning “single”) and Root: ton- (from Greek tonos, meaning “tone”)

Front: Define: moratorium (more-uh-tore-ee-um)
Back: n. suspension of activity Failing to secure the necessary signatures for a referendum, the group tried to secure a moratorium on gay marriages while their challenge was heard by the courts. Root: mora- (from Latin mora, meaning “delay”)

Front: Define: mores (more-ehyz)
Back: n. the accepted customs of a particular group She went against the mores of her community when she decided to keep her maiden name. Root: mor- (from Latin mores, meaning “customs”)

Front: Define: morphology (more-fol-uh-djee)
Back: n. the study of form or structure Her interest in drawing bushes and flowers logically led her to read up on plant morphology. Root: morph- (from Greek morphē, meaning “form”) and Suffix: -ology (from Greek logia, meaning “study of”)

Front: Define: muse (mewz)
Back: v. to reflect deeply on a subject The students mused over the message of the teacher's final lecture well after the class had ended. Root: mus- (from Greek Mousa, referring to the Muses, the inspirational goddesses of the arts)

Front: Define: nadir (nehy-dur)
Back: n. the lowest point Stevenson has said that the weather is generally the “very nadir” of interesting conversational topics. Root: nadir- (from Arabic nazir, meaning “opposite”)

Front: Define: nascent (neyss-unt)
Back: adj. just coming into existence The nascent after-school program was already attracting the interest of a lot of parents and students. Root: nasc- (from Latin nasci, meaning “to be born”)

Front: Define: nebulous (neb-yuh-luss)
Back: adj. unclear or vague Their plans for the new student center were as yet too nebulous to take to the board of directors for approval. Root: nebul- (from Latin nebula, meaning “mist” or “cloud”)

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a sharp satire mocking a person or group through an artistic medium v. to satirize or attack in such a style Hint: starts with “l”
Back: lampoon synonyms: parody, satire, spoof, ridicule The political cartoon was a biting lampoon of the mayor's controversial policies. The comedian loved to lampoon celebrities, turning their quirks into hilarious sketches.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ______ talent of the artist only emerged after years of practice. Hint: Starts with “l” and means “hidden but capable of emerging”.
Back: latent latent (lehy-tent) adj. present or existing but not currently visible

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. a pattern consisting of, or resembling, an interwoven frame made by crisscrossing strips Hint: starts with “l”
Back: lattice synonyms: mesh, filigree, net, grid, framework, trellis The garden was adorned with a beautiful lattice covered in climbing roses.

Front: Fill in the blank: The community gathered to ______ the firefighters for their bravery during the rescue. Hint: Starts with “l” and means “to praise highly”.
Back: laud laud (lawd) v. to praise or glorify

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to have an enlivening or lightening influence Hint: starts with “l”
Back: leaven synonyms: raise, lighten, stimulate, inspire Her enthusiasm helped to leaven the atmosphere during the otherwise dull meeting.

Front: Fill in the blank: After staying up late, I felt ______ and struggled to concentrate on my work. Hint: Starts with “l” and means “sluggish and lacking energy”.
Back: lethargic lethargic (luh-thar-djick) adj. physically or mentally slow

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to impose and collect n. a charge imposed Hint: starts with “l”
Back: levy synonyms: demand, exact, impose; tax, fee, charge, assessment The city council decided to levy a fine on homeowners who did not comply with the new regulations. The levy on sugary drinks was implemented to encourage healthier choices among consumers.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ______ attitude towards his coworkers made the office environment quite uncomfortable. Hint: Starts with “m” and means “unkind or inferior in quality”.
Back: mean mean (meen) adj. low in status or quality n. a point between two extremes

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to wander in a leisurely manner Hint: starts with “m”
Back: meander synonyms: drift, ramble, traipse, stroll, roam She liked to meander through the park on sunny afternoons.

Front: Fill in the blank: The buffet featured a ______ of international dishes, showcasing flavors from around the world. Hint: Starts with “m” and means “a mixture of different things”.
Back: medley medley (med-lee) n. a mixture of dissimilar things n. a musical composition of melodies from different songs

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a feeling of deep sadness adj. sad, dejected Hint: starts with “m”
Back: melancholy synonyms: dejected, downcast, sad, sorrowful, gloomy After the breakup, she was overwhelmed by a profound sense of melancholy that lingered for weeks. He wore a melancholy expression as he reminisced about his childhood.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ______ personality made it difficult for her friends to know how she would react to any situation. Hint: Starts with “m” and means “subject to sudden mood changes”.
Back: mercurial mercurial (mur-cure-ee-ul) adj. subject to sudden changes in mood adj. lively and quick

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. tedious, repetitive adj. characterized by a tone of unvarying pitch Hint: starts with “m”
Back: monotonous synonyms: droning, unchanging, repetitive, tedious The monotonous task of sorting through endless paperwork drained her energy. His monotonous voice made it hard for the audience to stay focused during the lecture.

Front: Fill in the blank: The government placed a ______ on new housing developments. Hint: Starts with “m” and means “a temporary suspension of activity”.
Back: moratorium moratorium (more-uh-tore-ee-um) adj. suspension of activity

Front: Name the vocab term: n. the accepted customs of a particular group Hint: starts with “m”
Back: mores synonyms: codes, ways, etiquette, ritual, customs, practices, norms Breaking the mores of her community led to widespread disapproval.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her research focused on the ______ of plant cells. Hint: Starts with “m” and means “the study of forms and structures”.
Back: morphology morphology (more-fol-uh-djee) n. the study of form or structure

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to reflect deeply on a subject Hint: starts with “m”
Back: muse synonyms: contemplate, ponder, reflect, ruminate She would often muse over the meaning of life during quiet walks.

Front: Fill in the blank: The company's financial struggles reached their ______ when it declared bankruptcy. Hint: Starts with “n” and means “the lowest point”.
Back: nadir nadir (nehy-dur) n. the lowest point

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. just coming into existence Hint: starts with “n”
Back: nascent synonyms: developing, beginning, emerging, fledgling The nascent technology showed great promise for the future.

Front: Fill in the blank: His plans for the future remained ______ and undefined. Hint: Starts with “n” and means “unclear or vague”.
Back: nebulous nebulous (neb-yuh-luss) adj. unclear or vague
